Based on the search results, I found comprehensive information about strategies for teaching classic literature like 1984 to high school students, particularly reluctant readers. Here are the key findings:

## Strategies for Teaching Classic Literature to Reluctant Readers

### Connect to Current Events and Relevant Themes

If you're reading 1984 — talk about censorship, the Facebook data breach, or how Alexa/Siri can monitor your behavior and predict your wants and needs.(no content)Teachers can focus on timeless themes and connections to current events in order to increase students engagement with classic literature.

### Multimedia and Cultural Connections

Intersperse film clips, songs, TV adaptations, plays, and interviews throughout a book unit to help with engagement.(no content)Show students that every book is part of a larger cultural/political/social climate.(no content)Sometimes we also used movies or recorded productions to fill in those gaps.

### Support Struggling Readers

Teenagers won't want to read the lower level version in class in front of their peers, but they will take this support if they know they're struggling.(no content)For my struggling readers, this meant perhaps reading an abridged version with supplemental vocabulary or analyzing a synopsis to fill in our gaps in understanding of characters and plot points.

### Reading Aloud and Creating Atmosphere

In addition, find time to read out loud during class. Make it cozy. Turn the lights down. Put up twinkly lights. Set the mood. High schoolers respond surprisingly well to this — we're never too old to hear a good story!

### Audiobooks and Alternative Formats

Try assigning the audio to the student as homework, so they can engage with the text in class.(no content)This can include implementing audiobooks, metacognitive markers, and more.

### Student Choice and Ownership

Allow students some choice of complementary books and types of reading and writing activities. When students choose what they read, what activities they engage in related to reading, and with whom they work, their motivation increases, as does the time they spend reading. They will assume greater ownership and responsibility for their engagement in learning.

### Collaborative Learning

Increase opportunities for students to collaborate during reading. Adolescents are motivated by working together. When students can collaborate socially on reading and literacy tasks, they find the work more motivating and often continue working even after completing the assigned task.

### Understanding Individual Needs

Before educators can try to help a reluctant reader become more engaged in reading, they need to understand why the student is reluctant to read. A student's reluctance could have many root causes: Are they struggling with particular reading skills? Are they disinterested in what they are reading? Are there tasks associated with reading that the student is resisting?

### Literature Circles and Discussion Groups

Fostering discussion through literature circles, book clubs, or other discussion protocols in response to reading provides a purpose for reading. It allows students to learn critical thinking analysis skills from one another through good conversation.

### Reader's Theater

Reader's Theater allows students to dramatize a book or story they have read. In Reader's Theater, students read aloud, rather than memorize short scripts based on a book. Reader's Theater is by nature a cooperative, social activity, as students work together to select, rehearse, and perform their piece.

These strategies emphasize making classic literature relevant to students' lives, providing multiple support systems, and creating engaging, collaborative learning environments that can help even the most reluctant readers connect with challenging texts like 1984.
